comment.body: yeah..., so the oxygen at the other side of the fabric isn't enough for it?

Great!, I posted a comment on zerome thinking what zeronet is commonly used for would not be well mixed with a POS but I see how genius this is now. What you describe sounds pretty nice given that it involves most of the basic functionality of a POS and how easy it is to add or replace terminals to it... Now, as far as I know POS systems tend to be really complex because you have to handle some accounting on them and also you must divide actions into really small sets so you can forbid specific actions for specific users (role permissions)... and handling drivers for printers and the rendering engine for receipts too.

You could export to word, excel or PDF and call it a day for the receipts but the other things may prove not so trivial, and now that we are at it let me remind you of an important thing you'll want to think early in design: Archiving. 3k products sounds nice but it may grow, so will the history of created sales and one day it may be too much for the pi to handle snappily, maybe some db indexes and calling optimized sql queries could help but I think the best is just to be able to pack a whole period of time and export it out of the running system so it becomes lean again.

The other nasty thing is power outages or interruptions, may they come from someone tripping over a cable, a kernel panic, storage media failure or just zeronet going haywire (hope your zerunet copes well with it) you should be prepared for those situations. How to recreate a broken db of a client? will you just assume newer db version as most correct version? you could keep two files, one for syncing every minute to proper zite db and another as a scratchfile so if something happens you'll only lose a minimal amount of progress and corruption will become pretty unlikely.

This post is pretty large by now, just wanted to say your project sounds really admirable and would love to hear more from it in the future. Kudos!
